title: A protocol to isolate bone marrow innate lymphoid cells for alymphoid mouse reconstitution
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Isolation of bone marrow progenitors from donor mice
Timing: 3–4 h
Sex and age-matched wildtype C57BL/6J (CD45.2+/+) or similar compatible background bone marrow donor mice are used to isolate bone marrow progenitors. Preferentially use mice between 6–10 weeks old.
Bones collection.
Euthanize mice using either CO2 (<20% displacement/minute) asphyxiation or cervical dislocation.
Note: Methods of euthanasia should be appropriate consistent with animal ethics regulations. Tissues should be harvested immediately after euthanasia of mice using aseptic procedures.
Remove the mouse hind limb femur and tibia from both legs. After removing muscles and connective tissue, place the bones in sterile PBS on ice.
Note: Hips and sternum can be also collected to improve cellular yields.
Extraction of bone marrow cells.
Under a PSP2 cell culture hood, transfer the bones into a mortar and crush the bones using a pestle in fresh sterile PBS. Continue to crush the bones until the bone debris becomes completely white, indicating that all the bone marrow cells have been released.
Filter the suspension through a 70 μm cell strainer in a 50 mL tube to remove the bone fragments. Rinse the mortar and the strainer using fresh sterile PBS.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Perform red blood cell lysis using 5 mL of ACK buffer.
After 2 min of incubation at 20°C, wash the cells by adding 10 times of the volume of ACK used of sterile PBS (final volume = 50 mL) to quench the lysis.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 10 mL and count cells using Trypan Blue exclusion cell viability staining using appropriate dilutions.

Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet with 1 mL per 107 cells of sterile cold MACS buffer.
Filter the suspension through a 70 μm cell strainer in a 15 mL tube to remove red blood cell debris.
Enrichment of IL-7Rα expressing bone marrow cells.
Centrifuge the bone marrow cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C, discard supernatant, and resuspend cells in fresh MACS buffer at a concentration of 25 × 107 cells/mL containing an anti-CD16/CD32 antibody (5 μg/mL).
Incubate cells on ice for 20 min, then wash by filling the tube with MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in MACS Buffer at a concentration of 50 × 107 cells/mL containing IL-7Rα -biotin antibody (CD127, A7R34; 5 μg/mL). Rely on the count performed in 2.f. Incubate for 40 min at 4°C.
After incubation, wash cells by adding 1 mL of MACS buffer per 5 × 107 cells (rely on the count performed in 2.f.) to the cell suspension.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in MACS buffer at a concentration of 50 × 107 cells/mL (rely on the count performed in 2.f). Add 10 μL of α-biotin magnetic microbeads (Miltenyi Biotec) per 107 cells.
Incubate cells with the microbeads for 30 min at 4°C.
After incubation, wash cells by adding 1 mL of MACS buffer per 5 × 107 cells (rely on the count performed in 2.f.).
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend up to 108 cells (rely on the count performed in 2.f.) in 500 μL of MACS buffer.

Proceed to magnetic separation using LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec).
Attach the MidiMACS Separator to the MACS MultiStand and place LS Column in the separator. Place a 15 mL collection tube under the LS Column to collect the negative (unlabeled) fraction.
Equilibrate the LS column by rinsing it with 3 mL of MACS Buffer. Wait until the buffer completely run through the column without letting the column dry.
Add the cell suspension on the column. Wash the columns three times with 3 mL of MACS Buffer.
After washing, add 5 mL of MACS Buffer on the column, remove the column from the MACS separator and place it on a new 15 mL collection tube to collect IL-7Rα+ cells. Use the plunger to flush out the labeled cells.
Critical: Cells are positively selected and IL-7Rα+ cells are retained within the column until their release via removal from the magnetic column stand and washing while using the plunger. Cells that flow through while the column is attached to the magnet during successive washes should be IL-7Rα negative. Keep these flow-through cells on ice as they can be used for single stained controls to appropriately set PMT voltages and compensation on the FACS.
Wash the recovered IL-7Rα+ cells in MACS buffer and centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant. Cells are ready to be stained with surface antibodies (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).

Prepare fresh antibody cocktails using MACS Buffer.
Flow cytometric cell sorting of bone marrow progenitors
Timing: 3–4 h

Enriched single cell suspension(s) will be stained with antibodies and a lineage cocktail (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) to discriminate different bone marrow progenitors using a FACS ARIA III Cell Sorter or a comparable Cell Sorter with similar characteristics. Minimal requirements consist of a FACS Cell Sorter with four lasers – violet (405 nm), blue (488 nm), yellow (561 nm) and red (640 nm) – and appropriate filters to optimally detect the fluorochromes detailed in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. Prepare collection tubes (e.g., 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes) containing 1 mL of sorting buffer to collect sorted cells. Keep all the tubes, solutions and sorted cells on ice (4°C) during the sort to maintain cell viability.
Staining of bone marrow progenitors.
Resuspend enriched cells in the antibody cocktail (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) together with the fixable viability stain 700 (100 μL/107 cells final volume in MACS Buffer) and stain for 30 min on ice. Protect from light from this point forward.
After incubation, wash cells by adding 10 times the volume of the antibody cocktail of MACS buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the cells at 1 × 107/mL of MACS buffer and keep the cell suspension on ice until cell sorting.
Isolation of ILC2p.
Before acquiring samples, set appropriate PMT voltages and compensation by using single stained controls. Adjust compensation using the same set of antibodies.
Note: Alternatively, antibodies against different markers can be used but they need to be coupled to the same fluorochromes for appropriate compensation. Commercially available beads for compensation can be used (e.g., UltraComp eBeads Plus compensation beads, InvitrogenTM, Cat# 01-3333-42) but the autofluorescence signal won’t be captured.
Perform cell sorting using a 70 μm nozzle with a sorting speed of 5,000–8,000 events/second.

Critical: Use aseptic procedures to keep progenitor cells sterile for in vivo injections.
Note: Where possible, a FACS Cell Sorter placed under a hood should be used to maintain complete sterility.
Isolate ILC2 progenitors based on the expression of the following parameters and the absence of expression of lineage markers (AF700 and APC-Cy7 antibody coupled fluorochromes): Lineage-IL-7Rα+Flt3-α4β7+c-kit-CD25+Sca-1+ (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

Figure 1. Gating strategy to isolate bone-marrow ILC progenitors
Note: It is expected to isolate between 2,000 – 4,000 of ILC2 progenitors from a single wildtype mouse donor.
Optional: The common and alpha lymphoid bone marrow progenitors can be isolated based on the expression of the following markers: Lineage-IL-7Rα+Flt3+α4β7-c-kit+ and Lineage-IL-7Rα+Flt3-α4β7+c-kit+CD25-, respectively (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Verify the purity of the sorted population by reanalysing 10 μL of cells, transferred into a new tube (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Figure 2. Purity check of the ILC2 progenitors
Critical: It is essential to evaluate the purity of isolated progenitors (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]) as contamination by other lymphoid progenitors can give rise to unwanted lymphoid cell subsets in recipient mice.
Wash isolated cell progenitors by adding 1 mL of sterile PBS/104 of cells.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Repeat steps 5e–f.
Resuspend cells in 200 μL and count cells using Trypan Blue exclusion cell viability staining using appropriate dilutions.
Resuspend cells in sterile PBS at 7.5–10 × 103 cells/mL and proceed immediately to the injections of progenitor cells in irradiated Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− mice.
Lymphoid cell reconstitution in Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− recipient mice
Timing: 6–8 weeks
The generation of bone marrow chimeras requires reconstitution of sublethally irradiated recipient mice with bone marrow-derived donor immune cells.
Note: The immunodeficient Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− mice receive a unique dose of 4.5 Gray irradiation to induce inflammation, promoting progenitor cell engraftment (Vély et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]).

Under a laminar flow hood (class II) cell culture hood, inject each Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− mouse intravenously with 200 μL of the donor cell suspension.
Note: Mice are monitored during 30 min to 1 h after injections and then daily by experienced animal technicians as per local ethics guidelines to ensure good animal welfare. Prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., neomycin sulfate) can be used to prevent infection during the two first weeks after transplantation. However, this is not usually necessary as the low dose irradiation does not induce complete myeloablation.
Perform ILC2 in vivo function assessment or ex vivo assays 6–8 weeks after bone marrow progenitor injection.
Note: This time-lapse is necessary to allow full reconstitution of the lymphoid compartment. While it is possible to analyze mice earlier than 6 weeks, the full development of ILC function requires 6–8 weeks. In ILC2-reconstituted Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− mice, we found a progressive increase of eosinophil frequency over time in the peripheral blood compared with control animals (Jacquelot et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). These transplanted mice achieved similar frequencies of eosinophils to ILC2 sufficient mice at ±6 weeks post ILC2p injections. These observations highlight that at least 6 weeks is required prior to analysis of ILC2 function in bone marrow-reconstituted Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− mice for accurate functional analyses.
Evaluation of reconstitution efficiency
Timing: 6–8 h

It is critical to establish the efficacy of ILC2 reconstitution in alymphoid Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− recipient mice to make sure that the observed phenotype is directly attributable to ILC2. This will distinguish ILC2 activity from other potential lymphoid populations which could result from contamination of ILC2p with other progenitor cells. Although carefully performed, this is rare, but can occur when limited separation of markers is observed during cell sorting affecting the purity of the ILC2p subset. For every reconstituted Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− recipient mice, we suggest analysing the frequency and number of lymphoid cells in the intestinal lamina propria which is known to be home of large numbers of both innate and adaptive immune cells, facilitating the evaluation of the reconstitution of the lymphoid cell compartment. Non-reconstituted non-irradiated Rag2−/−Il2rγ−/− and C57BL/6J mice should be analyzed in parallel and serve as controls. The protocol below will precisely describe the step-by-step isolation (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]) and analysis of intestinal immune cells.

(A) Identify Peyer’s patch (indicated by ∗) on the small intestine.
(B) The intestinal contents are gently removed.
(C) Small intestine is opened longitudinally and kept in PBS in a Petri dish.
(D) Small intestine is cut in small pieces.
(E) Tissue pieces are transferred in dissociation buffer.
(F and G) Tissues are filtered from dissociation buffer and washed.
(H) Tissue pieces are transferred in digestion buffer.
(I) After incubation, most of the tissues should have been digested.
(J) Remove remaining tissues through a cell strainer.
(K) Pellet the single cell suspension.
(L) Load the 80% Percoll from the bottom of the tube.
(M) Clear separation between the 40% Percoll containing cell suspension in top and the 80% Percoll below.

(N) After centrifugation the leukocyte are at the interface of the 40% and 80% Percoll.
(O) Leukocytes collected at the interface is rinsed in 10 mL of cold PBS to remove any Percoll from the solution and spun down to pellet.
Isolation of intestinal immune cells from the lamina propria.
Euthanize mice and collect small intestines in 4 mL PBS in 6 well plate on ice.
Separate the duodenum and ileum from the stomach and the caecum, respectively.
Remove successively the fat tissue and Peyer’s patches, when present, using tweezers and scissors.
Note: On average, there are between 6 to 9 Peyer’s patches per mouse that are distributed along the small intestine (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A, as indicated by ∗).
Critical: It is essential to ensure the small intestine is kept moist to avoid tissue dehydration and associated cell death. This may strongly impact cell recoveries and analysis.
Cut the small intestine into 4 parts, open them longitudinally (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B), and remove the intestinal contents by gently scraping the contents away from the mucosal surface.
Wash the small intestine in PBS (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Critical: It is important to gently remove the intestinal contents to avoid any damage to the underlying tissues.
Cut the tissue into 2 mm pieces (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D), transferred into 50 mL tubes containing 10 mL HBSS + 2% FBS.
Vortex vigorously for 10–20 s (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E) and filter the solution through a 100 μm cell strainer (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F).
Wash intestinal pieces with 20 mL HBSS + 2% FBS and transfer the pieces into a new 50 mL tube containing 20 mL of the dissociation solution.
Vortex the tube for 10–20 s and incubate for 40 min at 37°C under gentle shaking (230 rpm).
Note: The dissociation media allows the separation of the epithelial layer from the lamina propria.

After incubation, vortex the tubes vigorously for 10–20 s and filter the solution through a 100 μm cell strainer.
Critical: After vortex, the solution should appear cloudy (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G). This means that the epithelial layer has been effectively separated from the lamina propria of the small intestine.
Wash the intestinal pieces with 20 mL PBS.
Transfer intestinal pieces in a new 50 mL tube containing 8–10 mL of the digestion solution (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]H).
Optional: Cells from the epithelial layer can be collected and analyzed separately. Keep the solution at 4°C until step 8.o. Intraepithelial immune cells can be enriched by centrifugation on a 40%–80% Percoll gradient. Flow cytometric analysis of the immune cells can be performed after surface and intracellular staining using desired antibodies.
Critical: The enzymes are sensitive to freeze thaw cycles. The enzymatic cocktail must be prepared freshly every time you perform a gut digestion.
Vortex the tube vigorously for 20 s and incubate for 45 min at 37°C with gentle shaking (230 rpm).
After incubation, vortex the tubes vigorously for 20 s and filter the solution through a 100 μm cell strainer. Rinse the cell strainer with 30 mL PBS.
Critical: The solution should appear cloudy (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]I). Only minimal residual tissue should be seen on the cell strainer (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]J).
Centrifuge cells at 400 g for 7 min.
Note: A pellet should be clearly seen (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]K).
Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 6 mL of 40% Percoll.
Transfer cells into a 15 mL tube and underlay 2 mL of 80% Percoll using a glass Pasteur pipette (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]L).
Note: A clear separation of the two layers should be observed (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]M).
Centrifuge cells at 950 g for 20 min at 20°C without brake.

Note: A ring which contains lymphocytes should be visible at the interface (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]N).
Using a vacuum aspiration system, carefully remove and discard the top layer constituted by remaining epithelial cells to avoid contamination of your immune cell preparation.
Collect the lymphocytes at the interface and transfer them into 15 mL tube containing 10 mL of cold PBS.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Note: A pellet should be visible (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]O).
Discard supernatant and resuspend the cells in 5 mL cold PBS, count the cells using Trypan Blue, and transfer 1–2 × 106 cells in V-bottom 96 well plate for staining.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Incubate the cells with an anti-CD16/32 antibody (2.4G2 5 μg/mL in 50 μL of FACS buffer) for 20 min on ice.
Wash cells with 150 μL of FACS Buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Surface antibody staining.
Resuspend the cells in the antibody cocktail together with the fixable viability stain 700 (50 μL final volume in FACS Buffer) (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]) and stain for 30 min on ice.

Prepare fresh using FACS Buffer.
Note: Protect samples from light from all subsequent steps.
Wash cells with 150 μL of FACS Buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Cell fixation and permeabilization.
Prepare fixation buffer using the Fixation concentrate diluted (1 in 4) in the Fixation/Permeabilization diluent and fix/permeabilize cells (50 μL per sample) for 30 min on ice.
Prepare the permeabilization buffer (1×) by adding 9 volumes of distilled water to 1 volume of Permeabilization buffer (10×).
Wash cells with 150 μL of 1× permeabilization buffer.

Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Intracellular antibody staining.
Resuspend cells in the antibody cocktail (50 μL final volume prepared in 1× permeabilization buffer) (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]) and incubate for 45–60 min on ice.

Prepare antibody cocktail for intracellular staining using fresh 1× Permeabilization Buffer.
Wash cells with 200 μL 1× permeabilization buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 200 μL of 1× permeabilization buffer and store your samples at 4°C for no greater than 2–3 days prior to FACS acquisition.
Acquire your samples on a flow cytometer after appropriate compensation to detect your population of interest (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
